what.title: What is blindness?
what.text: Blindness does not always mean seeing nothing at all. Many blind and low-vision people can see light, shapes, or limited detail.

different.title: Everyone’s vision loss is different
different.text: There is no single “blind experience”. Some conditions affect the center, others the edges, contrast, or color perception. This site is an empathy demo, not a medical tool.

navigate.title: How do blind people navigate?
navigate.text: Many people use a white cane or guide dog together with memory, sound, touch, and spatial awareness. Indoors, texture changes, echoes, and landmarks help build a mental map.

tech.title: Assistive technology
tech.text: Screen readers (VoiceOver, NVDA, JAWS, TalkBack) read out interfaces. Keyboard shortcuts and gestures help users move by headings, links, and controls instead of using a mouse.

design.title: Good accessibility helps everyone
design.text: Clear headings, descriptive link text, form labels, and keyboard support remove barriers. Accessibility problems usually come from design choices, not from blindness itself.

cataract.title: Cataract (blur + glare) simulation
cataract.text: Cataracts can make vision cloudy with strong glare around lights. Try the mini-game and increase severity to feel how reading becomes harder.

macular.title: Macular degeneration simulation
macular.text: Central vision may be blocked or blurred while peripheral vision remains. Try the peripheral-shape game and change the spot size.

color.title: Color vision game
color.text: Color-vision differences can make some shades hard to distinguish. Try finding the different circle and see why “color only” design can fail.
